note.p: This is a late-stage draft (with printer's instructions) of the essay "Father Taylor (and Oratory)," which first appeared in Century Magazine in February 1887. The piece would later be reprinted in November Boughs. Edward Thompson Taylor was a Boston Methodist minister known for his powerful sermons, serving as the inspiration for Melville's "Father Mapple" in Moby Dick. Whitman went to hear Taylor speak on several occasions during his stay in Boston in 1860.

body.head: Father Taylor (and Oratory.)
body.p: I have never heard but one essentially perfect orator—one ‸that whowhose practicewho satisfied those depths of the emotional nature that in most cases go through life entirelyquite untouched, unfed—who held every hearer by spells which no man or mindconventionalism, high or low—nor any pride or composure, nor resistance of intellect—could stand against for ten minutes.
And by the way, is it not strange, of this first‑class genius

in the rarest and most profound of and beautiful of human
ity'shumanity's arts, that it will be necessary (so nearly forgotten and rubbed out is it his name by ‸the rushing currents whirls of the last twenty-five years.) to first inform the average current readers of to-day that he was an orthodox minister, of no particular celebrity who during a long life preached especially to Yankee sailors in an old fourth‑class church down by the wharves in Boston—who had practically been a sea‑faring man through his earlier years—and who died April 6, 1871, "just as the tide turned, going out with the ebb as an old salt should." Today this name is ‸now comparatively unknown, outside of Boston—even there, (though Dickens, Mrs. Jameson,
Dr. Bartol and Bishop Haven have commemorated him.) is merely mostly ‸but a reminiscence.

During my Boston visits ‸to "The Hub," in 1859 and '60 I several times saw and heard Father Taylor. In the spring or autumn, of quiet Sunday forenoons, I liked to go down early to the quaint ship‑cabin‑looking church where the old man ministered—to enter and leisurely scan the building the low celing, every thing strongly timbered, (polished and rubbed apparently,) the dark rich colors, the gallery, ‸ theall in half-light of every thing, and smell the aroma of old wood—and to watch the auditors, young sailors, mates, "matlows," officers, singly or in groups, as

they came in—their physiognomies forms, dress, gait, as they walked along the aisles—their postures, seating themselves in the rude, roomy, undoored, uncushioned, wooden pews—and the ‸evident effect upon them of place, occasion, and atmosphere.

The pulpit, rising ten or twelve feet high, against the rear wall, was backed by a large and significant mural painting in oil—showing out in bold lines and strong colors hues through the subdued light of the building—of a stormy sea, the waves high‑rolling and amid them an old‑style ship, all bent over, driving through the gale, and in great peril—a vivid and effectual piece of , not meant for the criticism
of artists (though I think it had merit even from that stand‑point.) but for its effect upon the congregation, and what it would convey to them.

Father Taylor was a moderate‑sized man, indeed almost small, (reminded me of old Booth, the great actor, and my favorite of those and preceding days.) well advanced in years, but alert ‸with mild blue or grey eyes, and with good presence and voice. Soon as he opened his mouth I ceased to pay any attention to church or audience or pictures or lights and shades; a ‸far more potent charm entirely swayed me. In the course of the sermon, (there was no sign of any MS., or reading from notes.) some of the

passages parts would be in the highest degree majestic and picturesque, colloquial in a severe sense, it often leaned to Biblical and oriental forms. Especially were all allusions to ships and the ocean and sailors' lives, of unrivalled power and life‑likeness, sometimes there were passages of fine language and composition even from the purist's point of view. An A few arguments, and of the best, but always brief and simple. ‸In the main, I should say of any of these discourses that the old Demosthenean rule and requirement of "action, action, action," first in its inward and then its outward sense, was the quality that had its leading fulfilment.

I rember ember I felt the deepest impression from the old man's praying ers, which invariably affected me to tears. Never, on any similar or other occasion, have I heard such impassioned pleading—such human‑harassing reproach (like Hamlet to his mother, in the closet)—such probing to the very depths of that latent conscience and remorse which probablly lie somewhere in the background of ever ‸life, every soul. For when Father Taylor reached or prayed, the rhetoric and art, the mere words, seems (which usually play such a big part) seemed altogether to disappear, and the live feeling advanced upon you and seized

you with a power before unknown. Everybody felt this marvellous and awful influence. One young sailor, a Rhode Islander, (who came every Sunday, and I got acquainted with, and talked to once or twice as we went away,) told me, "that must be the Holy Ghost we read of in the Testament."

I should be at a loss to make any comparison with other preachers or public speakers. When a child I had head Elias Hicks—and Father Taylor, (though so different in personal appearance, for Elias was of tall and most shapely form, with black eyes that blazed at times like meteors,) ‸always reminded me of him. Both had the same inner, apparently inexhaustible, fund of volcanic

passion—the same tenderness blended with a curious remorseles firmness, as of some surgeon operating on a beloved patient. Hearing such men somehow sends to the winds all the books, and formulas, and polished speaking, and rules of oratory.

Talking of oratory, why is it that ‸the unsophisticated practicers often strike deeper than the trained ones? Why do our expereinces perhaps of some local country exhorter—or often in the West or South at political meetings—leave the most graphic results? In my time I have head Webster, Clay, Edward Everett, Phillips, and such celebr√©s; yet for effects and performance I recall'd the minor but of life‑eloquence of man like John P Hale, Cassius Clay

and one or two of the old abolition "fanatics" ahead of all those stereotyped fames. Is not ‸—I sometimes question— the first, last, and most important quality of all for a in training for a public finished speaker, generally unknown unsought, unrecked off of both by teacher and pupil? Though may‑be it cannot be taught any how. At any rate, we need to clearly understand the distinction between oratory and elocution. Under the latter art, including some of the high order, there is indeed so scarcity in the United States, preachers lawyers, lecturers, &c. With all, there are seems to be few real orators—almost none.
I repeat it, and would dwell upon it (more as suggestion than ‸mere fact)—among all the brilliant lights of bar or stage I have

heard in my time—for years in New York and other cities I haunted the courts to witness notable trials, and have heard all the famous actors and actresses that have been in America the past fifty years—though I recall marvellous effects from one or other of them I never had any thing ‸in the way of vocal utterance to shake me through and through and so become fixed, with its accompaniments in my memory, as like those prayers and sermons as that and the whole story therein— Father Taylors personal electricity—the prone ship in the gale, and dashing wave and form, for background—in the little old sea‑church there in Boston, ‸those summer Sundays just before the war broke out.
